newsarticle.headline: What to Do When You Think You’re About to Get Fired
newsarticle.description: Whether you’re worried about getting the boot or getting a pink slip, here are some tips to protect yourself before the ax falls.
newsarticle.author: By WHITSON GORDON

newsarticle.headline: Julie Sweet of Accenture Could See Her Future. So She Quit Her Job.
newsarticle.description: Now, as Accenture’s chief executive of North America, Ms. Sweet helps major companies figure out the future. She is also working on creating true gender equality at the office.
newsarticle.author: By DAVID GELLES

newsarticle.headline: What to Do About an Overly Critical Boss
newsarticle.description: Starting a new job, an employee is already preparing to quit because of a supervisor who repeatedly levels unfair critiques and then apologizes.
newsarticle.author: By ROB WALKER

newsarticle.headline: Hiring People With Disabilities Is Good Business
newsarticle.description: Microsoft, Bank of America and CVS are just a few big companies that profit from their proactive employment practices.
newsarticle.author: By TED KENNEDY JR

newsarticle.headline: 7 Successful People Dish on Their Worst Job Interviews (and What They Learned)
newsarticle.description: We’ve all got one of *those* stories.
newsarticle.author: By JEN DOLL

newsarticle.headline: I Got Rejected 101 Times
newsarticle.description: Being told no is inevitable in most creative endeavors. But maybe I could win by losing.
newsarticle.author: By EMILY WINTER

newsarticle.headline: When a Manager in Another Department Ignores Your Emails
newsarticle.description: An employee looking to make a switch gets no response and wonders if it’s because he’s the wrong “type.” Here’s how to stop brooding and take useful action.
newsarticle.author: By ROB WALKER

newsarticle.headline: A.I. as Talent Scout: Unorthodox Hires, and Maybe Lower Pay
newsarticle.description: A form of artificial intelligence is being used to surface job candidates with the attributes of a perfect fit, even without conventional credentials.
newsarticle.author: By NOAM SCHEIBER

newsarticle.headline: Late to Launch: The Post-Collegiate Struggle
newsarticle.description: Despite a low unemployment rate, many young adults lack job prospects that mesh with their idealized vision of the post-college world.
newsarticle.author: By JULIE HALPERT

newsarticle.headline: ‘I Don’t Really Want to Work for Facebook.’ So Say Some Computer Science Students.
newsarticle.description: A job at Facebook is plum. But at a recent university hackathon, some young engineers showed a changing attitude toward working at the social network.
newsarticle.author: By NELLIE BOWLES

newsarticle.headline: When a New Colleague Sees Showing Up as Optional
newsarticle.description: Working remotely is popular and often useful. But it can cause friction when there is disagreement over how regularly an employee should actually be in the office.
newsarticle.author: By ROB WALKER

newsarticle.headline: Need a Handbag or a Tie to Land Your First Job? Borrow One With a Library Card
newsarticle.description: A new program at the New York Public Library lets job-seekers — particularly teenagers and young adults — check out accessories to wear to interviews.
newsarticle.author: By MELISSA GOMEZ

newsarticle.headline: At This Theater, All of the Directors Will Be Women
newsarticle.description: Anna Bergmann begins her role as the playhouse director of the Badisches State Theater in Germany with an all-female-directed season.
newsarticle.author: By SALLY McGRANE

newsarticle.headline: Lawyers Say They Face Persistent Racial and Gender Bias at Work
newsarticle.description: A study found that women and people of color in the legal profession felt they were held to higher standards than white men and received fewer opportunities.
newsarticle.author: By KAREN ZRAICK

newsarticle.headline: 8 Fast-Food Chains Will End ‘No-Poach’ Policies
newsarticle.description: The restaurants have pledged to end a practice that prohibited workers from switching jobs within the individual chains.
